As the organ ceases, and the music changes, Robert enters R. H.; he looks around him, and perceiving that none are near, he returns, and, seizing Bertram's arm, makes him enter the sacred precincts.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: We are alone and safe.

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: Confusion! what shall I do? within the boundaries of this sainted spot my evil power fails, and nought but wily art can obtain me my prize. Robert, wherefore hast thou forced me to enter here?

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: This spot is sacred; it is a place of refuge where none dare pursue. Yet, 'tis not safety that I care for. Alas! all I trusted in has this day betrayed me.

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: Except thy friend that loves thee, and wishes but thy happiness. Know'st thou not the reason of thy ill-success? the breaking of the magic branch has delivered Isabel to thy rival's power.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Can nothing snatch her from his arms? tell me!

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: There is still one way left to glut thy vengeance.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: I'll have it; be it what it may, I'll have it.

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: Hear me. The spirits of darkness—with whom thou hast already somewhat dealt—will be at thy command if thou wilt sign a compact pledging thyself theirs.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Give me revenge at any price!

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: Wilt thou consent to sign?

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: Come, then, out of this sacred ground, and full power and revenge are thine. Thou shalt exult over thy baffled rival, and hold thine Isabel within thine arms. Haste! away, away!

div.stage: (as they are departing, the organ is heard within the cathedral. Suddenly struck by it, Robert stops, rivetted in attention.)

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.l: How now? why dost thou still delay?

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.l: When for her son so dear

sp.speaker: Voices.
sp.l: Joy and peace to the blest!

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.l: The voice of Heav'n methinks is nigh,
And calls me back to virtue's way!

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.l: From this spot with me he must fly.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.l: Are thy soft and tuneful sounds!
Erring hearts, tho' wild as mine,

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.l: Whilst he tarries near this holy shrine

sp.speaker: Voices.
sp.l: Joy and peace to the blest!

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.l: Hope and peace fill my breast!

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.stage: (the organ and Voices cease, and Bertram approaches Robert.)

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: I wonder not at thy soul's emotion. The sounds thou hearest now bless the union of thy rival with Isabel.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Ha! that single word tears my heart, and revives my fury.
Begone—leave me! thou art my bitterest foe.

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: I! I, Robert, thy foe? I—who, out of the whole human race, love but thee? I, who would wish for all the treasures of the earth but to bestow them on thee alone?

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Mysterious being! Who, then, art thou?

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: Doth not the emotion that now shakes my heart and thine own, yet betray me to thee? Robert, rememberest thou not this morning? Didst thou not hear and mark the Norman minstrel's fearful recital—the fatal story of thy mother's woes? They were but too true.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Oh, my trembling soul!

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: Yes, a fallen Spirit was her lover and her husband. I—I was that lover, I was that husband.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Horror!

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: And now, Robert, my son, thou knowest me.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Thou—thou my father? Horror and hopeless misery!

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: I have deceived thee, but 'twas to gain thee ever mine. Now mark me well! If before the midnight hour thou dost not sign a bond which shall for evermore conjoin us, I must lose thee for ever; and the midnight hour is already nigh!

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Midnight! midnight! Isabel!
sp.stage: (the chimes of the cathedral strike the three quarters.)

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: Hark! there is but a quarter of an hour of hope left us. (with pressing anguish, and speaking rapidly.) Robert, my son! Oh! let not thy wretched father be for ever parted from thee! Sign! sign, and Isabel shall be thine—and honours and riches, and the joys of an eternal youth shall charm thy life!

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: It is decreed, and Hell bears the victory! Father, I'll not forsake thee; I am thine.

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: Oh joy!

div.stage: Enter Alice from the cathedral.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.p: 'Tis he; fortunate meeting.

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: Thou art resolved?

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Yes; be what thou wilt, I henceforth share thy fate.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.p: Ha! what do I hear?
Save me, Heaven! it is the Fiend.

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: What brings thee here?

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.p: Oh, Duke Robert, I have blessed, joyful tidings, which you will gladly hear. The false Prince of Grenada and his phantom train, approaching the southern gate, in vain attempted to cross the holy threshold, and, howling fearfully, vanished from sight!

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: I tremble.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.p: The horror-struck father, shuddering at his daughter's escape, consents to bless her, and messengers are seeking you to receive her hand. Follow me to the altar.

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: My son, go not; but follow me! Thou hast sworn to be mine.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.p: What do I hear? Horror!

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: Let us quickly away! Time flies, and midnight is about to strike.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.l: My brain is distracted! (to Bertram.) Speak thy will, and I'll obey.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: Oh, heav'ns, he's abus'd by the Demon's spell!

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.l: A superior claim must all o'ersway.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: Let no more thy heart rebel!
And from ill set him free!

lg.l: Oh despair! Hour of pain!
Ah, my son, my anguish see!
With thy father remain!
Let thy heart plead for me!

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.l: If all hope must be vain,
Let my death set me free!

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.stage: (drawing from his breast a black parchment, with hieroglyphic characters of blood traced on it.)
sp.l: See—see this parchment I now unfold,
The words there written thy hand must sign.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: By your hopes of mercy, hold!

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.stage: (eyeing the scroll with horror, and shrinking from it.)
sp.l: Wherefore there must my name be enrol'd?

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: Inspire me now, kind Heav'n, I pray!

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.stage: (Alice, at this moment, draws from her bosom the will of Robert's mother—a parchment with a large seal appended to it by a ribbon—and rushing between Bertram and Robert, places it in the latter's hand.)

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.l: Oh, Heav'n! 'Tis my lov'd mother's hand!
sp.stage: (burying his face in the paper with anguish.)

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.l: “O'er thee will watch from yonder sky!
“Fly from the snares, shun the dark spell,
“Of him by whom thy mother fell.”
sp.stage: (he lets fall the paper, which Alice hastily snatches up.)

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.l: Does then thy heart waver between us two?

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.l: I tremble! Horrid hour! Which way decide? What do?

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.stage: (without looking at Robert or Bertram, but reading aloud, impressively.)
sp.l: “O'er thee will watch from yonder sky!
“Fly from the snares, shun the dark spell,
sp.stage: (pointing to Bertram, without lifting her eyes from the paper.)

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.l: My son! Ah, turn thine eyes on me!
My pangs behold, my anguish see!
Fly not from him to whom thou'rt so dear!
Sign—and thou may'st defy all fear.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.stage: (seizing his hand on the other side.)

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.l: Fierce pangs that tear my heart and brain,
To 'scape your fury all hope is vain!

sp.speaker: Alice, Bertram, Robert.
sp.l: If all hope now be vain, &c.

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.l: Oh, my son! no more delay,

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.l: Mercy shew, and guide my way!
sp.stage: (the clock of the cathedral strikes MIDNIGHT.)

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: Ha! 'tis midnight! He's sav'd for e'er!

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.stage: (the earth opens beneath Bertram's feet, and he sinks enveloped in flames. Robert falls on the ground overcome with terror, while Alice has sunk on her knee in gratitude.)

div.stage: Dark clouds, accompanied by lightnings and thunder, for a while envelope all around; but, soon dispersing, the scene changes, and displays the whole interior of the cathedral brilliantly illuminated, with the entire Court, Knights, Ladies, &c., kneeling. The High Priest advances towards Robert— who has been partly raised from the ground by Alice still clinging to him—and taking his hand, joins it at the altar, with that of the Princess Isabel. The soft and increasing pea of the organ swells through the edifice, and the voices of all within the cathedral join in the—
div.label: FINALE CHORUS.
div.l: Joy and Peace to the Blest!
div.stage: CURTAIN.
